Paper-Nc:A:T:3. 93)2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W. 1 October 30, 19339192 ECONOMIC PRESSURE ON GERMANY.Report.I. Origin, Composition and Terms of Reference.THE Committee of Imperial Defence, at its meeting held on the 6th April, 1933,* agreed to approve the Summary of Measures that can be taken to exert Economic Pressure on an Enemy, prepared by the Advisory Committee on Trade Questions in Time of War, and to refer the question of exerting economic pressure in a situation not involving a formal declaration of war to the Advisory Committee.2. The Chairman of the Advisory Committee accordingly directed that a Sub-Committee should be set up, with the following composition and terms of reference : Composition.The Right Hon. Walter Elliot, M.C., M.P., Minister of Agriculture and'Fisheries (in the Chair). Sir Henry Fountain, K.C.M.G., C.B., Board of Trade. Sir William Malkin, K.C.M.G., C.B., K.C., Foreign Office. Mr. O. G. Sargent, C.M.G., Foreign Office. Captain H. R. Moore, D.S.O., R.N., Admiralty.Commander C. C. A. Allen, R.N., Committee of Imperial Defence, Secretary.Terms of Reference.3. To examine the general problem of exerting Economic Pressure on a foreign country in a situation not involving a formal declaration of war, and to ascertain to what extent our existing preparations can be adapted to such a situation.4. On the 12th May, 1933, before we had started our consideration of the general question of exerting economic pressure in a situation not involving a state of war, the Prime Minister directed that we should test our proposals by special application to the case of Germany. It appeared possible that Germany might attempt to rearm, and the problem for consideration was the circumstances in which measures could be taken to compel Observance by Germany of her obligations under Part V (Military, Naval and Air Clauses) of the Treaty of Versailles.5. We have therefore confined ourselves in this Report to considering whether effective economic pressure could be exerted on Germany with the object of compelling her to observe her disarmament obligations, in a situation where there has been no resort to war, and, consequently, Article 16 of the Covenant is not applicable.II. Preliminary Considerations.6. It is important to make plain the essential difference between the situation described in the preceding paragraph and that which would exist in a case where Article 16 was being applied. In the latter case, it would, under the Covenant, be the duty of all the Members of the League to co-operate in the exercise of their rights and obligations under Article 16, and they would, accordingly, be equally bound to abstain from economic and financial relations with Germany, and to take all steps in their power to make the exercise of economic pressure upon her effective. In the case which we are now considering, only a certain number of Powers directly interested to prevent the rearming nf Germany would be concerned; they would have no right to expect assistance under Article 16 from the other Members of the League (or, of course, from non-members); they would not possess the rights of belligerents, and, in fact,* O.I.D./258th Meeting, Minute 4. their activities would be confined to such economic pressure as they could effect by action taken within their own jurisdiction. The other countries of the world would have a perfect right to continue commercial relations with Germany, and the Powers concerned would have no right to interfere with them. The operations of those Powers would, in effect, be limited to such action as was taken during the Avar under trading with the enemy legislation.7. There is one possible hypothesis on which the considerations set forth in the preceding paragraph might not be applicable, or not fully applicable. The circumstances in which Germany rearmed might be such that her action would be generally regarded as constituting an immediate threat to the peace of the world, and the appropriate organs of the League, acting in pursuance of their peace-preserving functions under the Covenant, might (either under Article 11, Article 13 (4) or Article 15 (4)) recommend the members of the League to co-operate in exercising economic pressure against Germany, with a view to the termination of the threat to world peace. We deal with this possibility in a later passage of this report, but for the present we confine ourselves to the case where the economic action against Germany would be confined to a limited number of Powers, while the other nations of the world would retain their right to continue economic and financial relations with that country.8. In these circumstances the pressure which could be exercised by the Powers concerned would be confined to action on the following lines. They could refuse to allow any goods to be exported from their territory to a German destination, and they could refuse to admit to those territories any goods from Germany, or of German origin. Generally speaking, they could forbid all persons within their jurisdiction to have any financial or commercial relations with Germany. Ships flying their flags would not be allowed to trade to German ports or to carry German goods, nor would German ships be permitted to trade to their territories. The necessary powers to effect these results would have to be based on some common agreement between tho Governments concerned, reached by diplomatic negotiation, followed so far as this country is concerned by legislation on the lines of the Trading with the Enemy Acts, and, presumably, by some legislative procedure in most, at any rate, of the other countries concerned. Such action would, in the case of this country, and probably in that of some of the other countries concerned, involve a violation of the instruments which at present regulate their commercial relations with Germany, but as the foundation of the action taken would be Germany's violation of her treaty obligations in relation to disarmament, our action would presumably be justified on the grounds of retaliation. Our treaty obligations to third parties under such instruments as the Barcelona Transit Convention would, however, require consideration and might, in some respects, limit our freedom of action.III.-Countries ^ljkely. ,tO;, Co-operate.9. In estimating the extent to which Germany would be susceptible to the consequences of economic pressure of the character indicated above it is necessary to consider which Powers could be expected to co-operate in the exercise of such pressure. For the sake of argument it is justifiable to proceed on the following-hypotheses : (1) Of the Powers particularly concerned in preventing Germany's rearmament, the only ones which can initially be counted on to join in exercising economic pressure would be the United Kingdom, France, Belgium, Poland and the Little Entente (Czecho-Slovakia, Roumania and Yugo-Slavia).12) Of other Powers whose co-operation would be important if the economic pressure is to be effective, the most that can be forecast is as follows : (a) The British Dominions, the United States* and Italy (all of them except the United States being parties to the Treaty of Versailles) might, if political circumstances were favourable, be. ready to co-operate in. the exercise of economic pressure. The present report* Although the United States is not a party to the Treaty of Versailles, her own Treaty of Peace with Germany reproduces all the disarmament provisions of that Treaty, thereby giving the United States a locus standi for insisting- upon their observance.[9192] n 2 is based on the assumption that this would be the case. In any case it may be said straight away that such pressure could not possibly produce the desired result unless the United States, and (at any rate) some of the Dominions, participated in it.(b) Russia is not a party to the Treaty of Versailles and would certainly refuse to co-operate. The Argentine also is not a party to the Treaty, and it is highly problematical whether she would agree to co-operate; moreover, her example would probably be followed in a greater or lesser degree by the rest of the Southern and Central American States, even though some of them, such as Brazil, are parties to the Versailles Treaty. The present report is based on the assumption therefore that none of these countries would co-operate.(c) There remain the neighbours of Germany who are not parties to the Treaty of Versailles, i.e., Holland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Baltic States, Austria and Switzerland. Although some or all of these States might be in sympathy with the object of the boycotting Powers, it is doubtful whether any of them would be ready to co-operate unless those Powers were prepared to give them a guarantee of security against German aggression or retaliation. In this report it is assumed that none of these States would co-operate.IV. League Machinery.10. Before anything in the nature of economic pressure could be applied, it would be necessary for the Powers exercising such pressure to proceed in accordance with their Treaty obligations in order to seek a settlement of the dispute. A Memorandum by the Foreign Office is attached as an Appendix, the relevant conclusions of which are as follows : " (i) In the event of a violation by Germany of her disarmament obligations, it is essential that the complaining Powers should proceed in strict accordance with their obligations under the Covenant and the Treaty of Locarno, even if the coercive measures contemplated do not involve the use of force;(ii) Normally, the first step would be a request to the Council of the League of Nations to carry out an investigation under Article 213 of the Treaty of Versailles;(iii) If the result of the investigation is to establish facts regarded as constituting a violation of Germany's obligations, the resulting dispute must, if between Germany and France or Germany and Belgium, be submitted, according to its nature, either to judicial settlement or to i conciliation, followed, if necessary, by reference to the League under Article 15. If between Germany and the United Kingdom, it must go either to the Permanent Court or to the Council;(iv) In the event of Germany refusing -to, submit the dispute to judicial settlement or to comply with ah arbitral or judicial decision, the matter must be brought before the Council under the last paragraph of Article 5 of Locarno;* * * * * *(vii) Subject to any difficulties arising from instruments like commercial treaties, measures, such as economic pressure,.not involving the use of force would be permissible (whether or not the Council had made a unanimous recommendation to that effect), assuming that the procedure prescribed for the settlement of the dispute had been adopted."11. It is the action to be taken under conclusion (vii) above which forms the subject of our Report.V. "Pacific Blockade."12. At this stage it may be convenient to consider one form of action of which the possibility may be suggested, i.e., a so-called " pacific blockade " of German ports. There have in the past been several instances of pressure of this sort being effectively exercised, but never against a naval Power of any importance. For this and the following additional reasons we think that the possibility of its being effectively applied in the present case must be ruled out. In the first place, the precedents are in favour of the view that a pacific blockade cannot be enforced against the merchant ships of third parties, and there is at least one case on record where this country successfully maintained this contention. This being so, it seems certain that any attempt to enforce a pacific blockade against countries not participating in the economic measures against Germany would produce the most serious difficulties; but if the blockade were not so enforced, it would be bound to be ineffective. In the second place, it is, at any rate, doubtful whether, under the Covenant and other instruments, such as the Pact of Paris, a pacific blockade is permissible in any circumstances except where it is imposed with the authority of the League of Nations.13. Further, if any attempt to use the naval forces of the participating Powers to enforce a policy of economic pressure were made, and Germany provided naval escort for shipping destined to or leaving German ports, the naval forces of the participating Powers would either have to let them pass unmolested or attack the escorting man-of-war. In these circumstances a state of war might ensue, and the participating Power whose ship resorted to force might be represented as the primary aggressor.VI. German Trade.(Note. Powers we have assumed would be co-operating are printed in heavy type.)14. This Section of our Report is devoted to a study of German Trade, while the next Section reviews the possible effects of economic pressure on Germany in the circumstances envisaged. In Section VIII we consider the effect on the United Kingdom of such a policy. Owing to the widespread nature of our trade and business connections, the reactions might fall more heavily on us than on the other Powers applying pressure.Imports Food Products. 15. Germany is normally self-supporting in meat, potatoes, and cereals for both bread and fodder. As regards fish and fish products, normally half the German supplies are imported, mainly from the United Kingdom, Norway and the Netherlands, but the German fishing fleet, if allowed to extend its opera-tions, is sufficiently large to be capable of supplying a considerable part of the fish now imported.16. Germany is dependent as to 25 per cent, on imported eggs, and relies to a considerable extent on imports of butter and cheese. The principal sources of supply for these are : Butter : Denmark and Russia.Cheese : The;Netherlands: : ' -17. The main food commodities for which Germany is wholly dependent upon overseas supplies are rice, coffee and cocoa, the principal sources of supply being India, Brazil and Central America, and British West Africa respectively.18. The most important group of food-stuffs for which Germany is practically wholly dependent upon outside sources of supply is oil seeds and nuts, edible oils and fats, and oil-seed cake; the principal sources of supply for these commodities are: The Whale Fisheries, Newfoundland, for oils and fats; Manchuria and the Argentine for oil seeds and nuts; Denmark, India, Russia and France for oil-seed cake.Imports Raw Materials. 19. Germany is entirely dependent upon outside sources of supply for the -following raw materials, the principal sources of which are as follows : Cotton : The United States. Flax : Russia. Hemp : Italy. Jute: India.Rubber: Dutch East Indies, India and British Malaya. 20. In addition to the above, Germany is almost entirely dependent on imported supplies of wool, largely from Australia, South Africa and the Argentine. It would appear that stocks of wool do not exceed one month's supply, and those of cotton do not exceed about two months' supply. Stocks of rubber may represent as much as one year's supply.21. As regards hides, Germany is dependent on imports to the extent of about 50 per cent, of her requirements; the principal source of supply being the Argentine.22. Imports of iron ore, mainly from Sweden, represent about two-thirds of the total supply. Stocks of iron ore were reported last April to represent about 10 months' normal import, and are probably now somewhat larger. Stocks of pig iron are also reported to be very large, while it is known that Germany has for some time been importing large quantities of steel scrap.23. Germany is practically entirely dependent upon imported copper and tin. As regards the former, the principal sources of supply are South Africa, the United States, Chile, Belgium and the Belgian Congo, and stocks were reported in April to represent not more than two or three months' supply, but have increased recently, and it is thought that stocks have nearly doubled. Tin is imported from many different countries; no information as regards stocks of tin is available.24. In addition, Germany is dependent in normal times to a considerable extent on imports of non-ferrous metals and ores, as shown below : Bauxite ... Hungary, 44 per cent.; France, 28 per cent.; Italy,27 per cent.Zinc metal ... Russia, 48 per cent.; India, 40 per cent.cent, from imported ore. Manganese ore ... Russia, 48 per cent.; India, 40 per cent. Pyrites ... Spain, 60 per cent.; Norway, 30 per cent.Nickel... ... Canada.Quicksilver ... Italy; Spain.Wolfram (Tung- The world sources of supply are approximately as stem ore) follows: China, 8,000; India, 2,500; UnitedStates, 1,000; all tons per year, and smaller quantities from Malaya, Australia, Spain and Portugal.These non-ferrous metals and ores are of particular value for the production of munitions, and it is interesting to note that during the first six months of 1933 Germany's direct imports of nickel from Canada have doubled as compared with the corresponding period of 1932, while Holland, through which Westphalian industries import heavily via Rotterdam, has taken six times as much nickel oxide and three times as much fine nickel. - - - ......Petroleum Products.25. The total quantity of petroleum products imported into Germany amounts to some 2^ million tons per annum; the total consumption is over 3 million tons, the balance being provided from indigenous sources. In 1932 more than half the imports of petroleum products came from the United States of America and Russia.VII. Possible Effects on Germany of Economic Pressure.26. In considering the extent to which Germany could evade the consequences of economic pressure, it is necessary to analyse the foregoing study of Gei'many's import trade in relation to the countries we have assumed would, or would not, co-operate in exerting economic pressure. It must always be remembered that, to the extent to which re-exportation through non-participating countries is practicable, the supplies from whatever original source will become available to Germany. Imports Food Products.27. The chief German imports of food products derived wholly or partly from the participating Powers are as follows : Fish: United Kingdom, Norway, Netherlands.As stated in paragraph 15, Germany could extend the operation of her fishing fleet, and would retain her sources of supply in Norway and the Netherlands, which might be extended.Rice: India.China might afford an alternative source of supply. Oil Seed Cakes: India, France, Russia.German supplies from Russia could be augmented.28. In regard to food products, it would appear that economic pressure in the circumstances envisaged would have little, if any, material effect.Imports Raw Materials.29. Germany's essential raw materials, so far as the participating Powers form part or the whole of the sources of supply, are as follows : Cotton: United States of America.Russia is a potential source of supply, but Germany might experience a shortage of this commodity when existing stocks ran low. Brazil, Central America and China afford alternative sources of supply.Wool: Australia, South Africa, Argentina.Germany would lose the first two sources of supply, but by increasing her imports from the Argentine and drawing on a potential source of supply from Russia she would go some way towards meeting her requirements.Petroleum Prodtocts : United States of America, Russia.The deficiency caused by the stoppage of imports from the United States of America could, to a certain extent, be made good by increasing the output of crude oil in Germany and by increasing the production of oil products from coal. In addition to Russia there would be available as alternative sources of supply Venezuela, Mexico and the Dutch East Indies, and in view of the over-production of oil products, Germany should experience little difficulty in counteracting the cessation of supplies from the United States of America.Rubber: India, British Malaya and the Dutch East Indies.The deficiency caused by the stoppage of imports from India and British Malaya could be made good by increasing the imports from the Dutch East Indies. As in the case of petroleum products there is an over-production of rubber in the world at the present time.Hemp : Italy.Germany would lose this source of supply. Alternative sources of supply are Russia and the Baltic States.Jute : India.Germany would lose this source of -supply, for which there is no. alternative. Substitutes for jute could, however, be employed.Copper: United States of America, Belgium, Belgian Congo, South africa and Chile.As Germany would lose four of her principal sources of supply she might experience some difficulty in maintaining her supplies.Nickel: Canada.Germany might experience difficulty in obtaining adequate supplies of nickel. It should be noted, however, that Norway supplied Germany with considerable quantities of nickel during the war and has, in recent years, produced about 800 tons of nickel per annum. Other non-ferrous metals and ores Germany would experience some difficulty over other non-ferrous metals-and ores such as zinc metal (United States of America, Canada, Australia) and manganese (Russia, India).30. In this connection it must be remembered .that Germany acquired valuable information in the war with regard to the utilisation of substitutes for many strategic raw materials, and this information will be available for future use in addition to any post-war work in this direction.31. Another factor to be borne in mind is that there is, generally speaking, a large over-production of most commodities in the world to-day, the rarer metals and ores excepted, and alternative sources of supply for many imports should be readily available.32. It would appear, therefore, so far as raw materials are concerned, that, with the possible exception of certain metals and ores, such as copper, nickel, zinc metal, &c, the effect of economic pressure of the character proposed would not be great.33. It has been suggested that if Germany were, in fact, aiming at speedy and complete rearmament, the cutting off of metals and ores required for munition making would produce an immediate effect and would ultimately force her to submit, even if other commodities were still available to her. This argument could only be valid, if in the meantime Germany had not laid up stocks of the metals and ores in question and in so far as the participating Powers can control these particular supplies. It has been indicated above that in the case of copper and nickel at least considerable stocks have already been accumulated, whilst in the case of some other metals and ores adequate supplies could be obtained from or through non-participating countries.Exports.34. The effects upon Germany of a restriction of her exports can be considered under two heads : (1) The effect internally upon Germany of a partial cessation of themanufacture of goods for export; (2) The effect upon her purchasing power of a reduction of her export markets.35. The first effect would be felt, whether or not the embargo upon imports was made effective. The result of cutting down the German export trade would be a rise in the level of unemployment in Germany proportionate to the diminution of German trade.36. As regards the second effect that is the effect on Germany's purchasing power Germany 's chief markets are Soviet Russia, the United Kingdom, France, Holland, Switzerland, the United States of America and Belgium. Of these, it has been assumed that the United Kingdom, United States, France and Belgium would be co-operating in the action proposed.37. We have considered the possibility of bringing pressure to bear on Germany merely by a decision on the part of the countries concerned to exclude German goods, but have been forced to the conclusion that there would be too many countries affording export markets to Germany to allow of material results being achieved. In any event, the disastrous financial consequences indicated later in this Report as certain to follow a policy of economic pressure on Germany would in no way be mitigated by the adoption of this less comprehensive policy.German Shipping.38. The bulk of German shipping is engaged in services to or from German ports. As it is assumed that all countries participating would be debarred from using German ships and from supplying them with bunkers and essential stores, it follows that economic pressure, if effective, would result in the laying up of a considerable quantity of German shipping. Finance.39. The immediate effect of economic pressure would be to transform into -a complete default the partial suspension of Germany's external obligations which is already in operation, and thereby to relieve German banks and industry of a substantial volume of debt. There might also be danger of repudiation in certain directions. German credit abroad would, no doubt, be destroyed, but it is probable that there is still a large volume of German assets in foreign countries, and it would be extremely difficult to prevent the withdrawal of such balances.Loopholes.40. The period that would necessarily be taken to operate the machinery for the settlement of the dispute, provided by the Covenant of the League of Nations and the Treaties of Locarno (see paragraph 10) would probably enable Germany to accumulate extensive reserves of specific commodities before economic pressure could be applied. In addition we have indicated in the foregoing paragraphs that considerable loopholes in the form of alternative sources of supply would exist whereby Germany could evade the consequences of economic pressure even when in full operation. From the experience of the War, we anticipate that re-export trade would very soon spring up in non-participating countries which it would be quite impossible to stop and would, to a considerable extent, circumvent the action taken by the participating Powers.41. Apart from the opportunities for trade by countries not participating in the application of economic pressure, we doubt, particularly in view of the number of limitrophe States, involving numerous avenues of .approach to Germany, whether the Powers pledged to impose economic pressure could be entirely relied upon to make it effective. Though in the case under consideration, national sentiment might be hostile towards Germany, there would, in all probability, be many people both in this country and in other countries partici-pating in the measures, who either disapproved of the policy altogether, or, who were prepared to seize the opportunity to make a profit by evading the restrictions. The moral deterrent to evasion would be weak; the inducement to profit strong.42. In view of these loopholes we consider it highly problematical whether even with the co-operation of the Powers mentioned it would be possible to exert economic pressure which would be effective.VIII. Effect on the United Kingdom.43. In paragraph 14 we pointed out that whatever the effect of economic pressure on Germany, there would be a considerable reaction on the trade of the United Kingdom as well as of the Dominions,- India and the Colonies. This Section of our Report is devoted to a detailed survey of the effect on the trade of the United Kingdom in particular, under the following headings : Imports. . .,!(., . i Exports. . Shipping. The Coal Trade. Finance.Imports from Germany. Food Products.44. The principal imports under this head are sugar, wheat, eggs, fruit, potatoes, wines, meat and yeast. With the exception of yeast these are all food-stuffs in which there is an over-supply in the world. Yeast might cause some immediate difficulty, as about 30 per cent, of our imports in 1931 came from Germany, but increased supplies should be readily forthcoming from other Continental sources and from home production.Raw Materials.45. The principal imports are wood pulp, hides and skins, furs, timber, vegetable oils and agricultural seeds. All these materials are readily obtainable from, other sources at home or abroad. Temporary difficulties might arise over the cessation of supplies of a few special materials, but, generally speaking, substitutes are readily available.[9192] c Manufactured Goods.46. In general, our manufactures and those of Germany are competitive, and no difficulties as to supplies should arise except in specialised products.47. There are a number of cases where German manufactures are the raw material of our industries, and considerable dislocation would be caused while supplies from home and foreign sources were being expanded. Potash, for instance, an important fertilizer, is drawn largely from Germany, and although the French control the Alsace deposits and supplies are beginning to arrive from the Dead Sea, there might be a serious temporary shortage.48. A similar position might arise with such products as acetic anhydride and oxalic acid, which are used in the manufacture of dyes or in dyeing itself, and some classes of synthetic dyes would not be procurable.49. There might also be some difficulties over chemical porcelain, certain scientific and optical glassware, specialised machine tools and machinery (especially textile), hosiery latch needles and electric carbons.50. There would also be a cessation of supply of many fine chemicals (mainly used as drugs) subject to Key Industry Duty. Many of them could, of course, be made here after an experimental period and at a cost.Exports to Germany.51. The main items in our export trade with Germany are as follows : Fish, coal, raw wool, waste and noils, cotton yarn, cotton piece-goods, woollen and worsted yarns, woollen worsted tissues, and machinery.52. Germany is by far our most important market for fish, especially cured herrings. The loss of the German trade might be a serious matter for the fishing-industry. Germany is our main market for raw wool, waste and noils.53. Cotton yarns account for nearly one-third of our total exports to Germany of manufactured articles, and it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the loss of the German market would be of serious consequence to the fine spinning section of the Lancashire industry. This loss might be partially offset by obtaining some of the German trade in the goods for which these yarns are used, but it is evident that considerable dislocation and loss of trade would result.54. The machinery industry would, no doubt, gain far more from a cessation of the imports from Germany than it would lose from the loss of the German market, and, similarly, the woollen and worsted industry should, on balance, gain considerably from a cessation of trade with Germany.'55. It has also to be remembered that there is a very considerable re-export trade to Germany; the main items are butter, tea, coffee, furskins, rubber, raw wool and leather.56. Finally, certain of the Dominions and Colonies have a very valuable direct trade with Germany, particularly British India, British East, South and West Africa, the Commonwealth of Australia and Canada.British Shipping.57. Economic pressure on Germany would affect British shipping in various directions. There is a large volume of trade between this country and Germany amounting in 1931 to approximately 96 million. Of the cargoes carried, probably about one-third are in British bottoms and the effect so far as the trade was not replaced by purchases and sales from and to other countries on the British lines engaged in this trade would be serious. Ten to fifteen per cent, of British coastal and home trade tonnage is engaged in trading with Germany.58. In addition to the trade between this country and Germany, the trade of the Empire with that country amounts to approximately 57 million and of cargoes carried, probably 50 per cent, go in British ships. This traffic would also be lost, except so far as the trade was replaced by purchases and sales from and to other countries. nOn the other hand, the restricted field for German tonnage would mean certain benefits to British shipping.59. At the present time many of the big German passenger liners call at ports in the United Kingdom, both inwards and outwards, and convey considerable numbers of British passengers, whereas the big British passenger liners do not call at German ports. The effect of stopping the German liners would be to bring increased passenger traffic to the British ships.60. Under existing conditions many British overseas cargo liners call at German ports both outwards and inwards, whereas German cargo liners do not as a rule call at United Kingdom ports. The action proposed would thus affect the earnings of the former ships to a certain extent, especially in respect to deliveries to German ports. It is doubtful whether they really get much outward German cargo. The main reasons for the Continental calls are to maintain established services.61. The extent to which British overseas cargo liners will benefit by the restricted operations of German shipping will depend largely on the proportion of German export trade in manufactures which will be secured by this country as British ships would then carry not only the additional exports, but the resulting additional raw materials required in the United Kingdom.62. In addition to the above it is reasonable to assume that a proportion of Germany's exports of such goods as coal, machinery, chemicals, sugar, &c, would be secured by the United Kingdom, thus providing additional employment for British coastal trade ships and tramps.The Immediate Effect on United Kingdom Coal Trade.63. The embargo on United Kingdom exports of coal and coke to Germany would result in an immediate loss to the United Kingdom of about 225,000 tons a month, or over 2,750,000 tons a year.64. As regards other markets we might expect to gain part only of the supplies to France and Belgium since some of the demand would be met by additional home production. In Italy we might hope to replace the German coal almost entirely by British coal.On these assumptions the gains on these countries can be estimated at Tons.France ... ... ... ... 2,750,000Belgium ... ... ... ... 1,500,000Italy ... ....... ... 1,250,0005,500,000Less loss in Germany ... ... 2,750,000Net gain ... ... ... 2,750,000It must, however, be remembered that Germany will certainly attack us by a price-cutting campaign in every open market and we must expect to lose immediately, both in quantity and price, more than the net gain shown above.Possible Permanent Effect on United Kingdom Coal Trade.65. It is not inconceivable that when the economic pressure was withdrawn Germany might refuse to resume the Coal Agreement at present in force, and might even go so far as to take steps to prohibit imports for bunkers for use in the free harbours. In this event we would stand to lose at least 180,000 tons a month, or, in the extreme case, 225,000 tons per month.66. It has to be remembered also, that even if trade with Germany in coal were resumed, while Germany would almost certainly be able to continue to [9192] c 2 displace us in neutral markets, we should, with equal certainty, find the utmost difficulty in selling coal in Germany, and our loss would be permanent.Financial Effects.67. Germany owes the City of London on short-term, in respect of acceptance and other credits, a sum of between 40 and 50 million.These are covered by the Standstill Agreement, and so long as this is in being interest is regularly paid and the bills constitute good assets in the hands of the holders. The imposition of economic pressure would inevitably bring the Standstill Agreement to an end, and interest would cease to be paid. The financial houses concerned would remain liable for the bills, and, in view of the doubtful prospect of ultimately recovering funds from Germany, would be imminently threatened with insolvency.68. Such a state of affairs would, undoubtedly, entail a financial crisis of the first magnitude unless special steps were taken to assist the financial houses concerned.69. There is also a considerable amount of short-term debts not covered by the Standstill Agreement, which would become irrecoverable (amount 15 to 20 million).In addition, the United Kingdom is a very large holder of long-term German bonds (amount uncertain, possibly 80 million nominal).70. Finally, the United Kingdom is interested to a substantial degree in manufacture and distribution within Germany. Possible Action by the League.71. Our Report has hitherto proceeded on the basis that the exercise of economic pressure upon Germany is confined to a limited number of Powers particularly interested in preventing German rearmament. We indicated, however, in paragraph 7 that, in the event of the circumstances of Germany's rearmament being such as to be generally regarded as constituting a threat to the peace of the world;' there might be a possibility of action by a larger number of Powers as the result of the operation of the peace-preserving machinery of the League of Nations. The situation contemplated is that the Council or the Assembly, acting under Article 11, Article 13 (4) or Article 15 (4) of the Covenant, recommends to the Members of the League the use of economic pressure as a means of terminating the threat to the peace of the world. The possibility of such action has been suggested in discussions in the past at Geneva, particularly in connection with Article 11. It involves (a) a unanimous recom-mendation to that effect by the Council; (b) the acceptance of the recommendation by all the Members of the League, or at any rate a sufficient number to enable the action in question to be taken effectively. These possibilities are obviously of a speculative character, and much would turn on the circumstances as they presented themselves and the view of Germany's action which was taken by world opinion.72. In order not to confuse the issue, we have purposely refrained from a detailed consideration of the question from this angle. If it is considered necessary to examine this aspect of the question, we suggest that it should form the subject of a separate Report. In 1924 and 1925, the Council of the League approved rules for the conduct of an enquiry of this nature; and on the 11th December, 1926, the Council adopted a report (Annex II) which elucidated these rules.(') According to this report, " The Council of the League of Nations, acting by a majority vote, shall decide in conformity with Article 213 of the Treaty of Versailles whether it is necessary to hold an investigation, and it shall then specify the object and the limits of such investigation. If the result of the investigation is to establish facts which any of the ex-Allies considers to constitute a violation by Germany of an engagement into which she entered under the Treaty of Versailles, there arises between the ex-Ally concerned and Germany a dispute. Hurst on the Powers of the League of Nations under Article 213 of the Treaty of Versailles (embodied in a Foreign Office Letter to War Office, Admiralty and Air Ministry of January 27, 1925).NO provision in the Treaty of Versailles, Part V, or in the Covenant of the League of Nations, confers any general power upon the League or upon the Council of the League to enforce the provisions of treaties in general or of the disarmament clauses of the Treaty of Versailles in particular. What Article 213 does is to confer upon the Council of the League the power to hold investigations, i.e., to enquire into and determine the facts.The military, naval and air clauses of the Treaty of Versailles providing for the disarmament of Germany fall into two groups : (a) Those which impose a transitory obligation upon Germany which she was bound to fulfil within a limited period, and (b) those which impose upon her permanent obligations, such as the provision relating to the construction or acquisition of submarines or that relating to compulsory military service. Special organisations were set up to control the execution of the transitory clauses (see Article 203), and for the permanent clauses the League of Nations was given the right of investigation. This right of investigation is the sole function conferred upon the League in connexion with Part V (the military clauses).One of the great difficulties in the way of any scheme for the limitation of armaments is the difficulty of ensuring its observance, and the chief difficulty in the way of ensuring observance is the difficulty of getting at the truth. Presumably, therefore, it was considered by the framers of Part V of the Treaty of Versailles that if the League was given a power which would enable it to investigate the facts and get at the truth, the probability of Germany violating the disarmament clauses would be greatly minimised, if not entirely removed.The Treaty of Versailles has no status different from other treaties, and the League of Nations has not been given any general function or duty of enforcing the provisions of all treaties. The action which the Council can take on the report of a commission of investigation is thus very limited. Such a report will establish the fact whether or not a breach of the treaty has been committed. The type of decision which can then be taken by the Council is, for instance, to publish the report, or to communicate it to all the other members of the League, or to consider the question of strengthening the machinery for making further investigations in the future. The Council certainly has not the power of setting all the other members of the League in motion for the purpose of applying coercion to Germany merely because she has broken a treaty engagement.What, then, is the position where an investigation ordered by the Council under Article 213 results in the establishing of some violation by Germany of her treaty engagements under the military, naval or air clauses of the Treaty of Versailles % It is that Germany has violated the engagements which she has entered into with the other parties to the Treaty of Versailles. There would then arise between them, and Germany a dispute, but it is a dispute in which the League of Nations will not play the part of a party to the dispute. The role of the League will be that of endeavouring to prevent war and of bringing the parties to the dispute to an amicable solution. The parties to the dispute will be Germany on the one side, and one or more of the Allies on the other. The role of the League under Article 213 will have been fulfilled by its enquiry into and determination of facts, and its role under the articles of the Covenant as an organisation for endeavouring to bring the disputants to a harmonious conclusion of their quarrel will begin. The Council of the League will then act under Article 11 of the Covenant (which necessitates the concurrence of the parties to the dispute in any action thus taken, as well as unanimity of all other members of the League represented on the Council), or, under Article 15, which excludes the parties to the dispute from the calculation with regard to unanimity and provides also what is to happen if the non-parties to the dispute cannot arrive at a unanimous conclusion among themselves.[9192]E Extracts from the correspondence respecting the United States proposal for the renunciation of war (Cmd. 3109 and 3153).THE exchange of correspondence which preceded the signature of the Kellogg Pact contains certain passages in which the French, German, British and United States Governments define their conception of the relation of the Pact to the Covenant of the League of Nations and incidentally to the Locarno Treaty.On the 26th March, 1928, the French Ambassador in Washington informed the United States Government that "if it is clearly understood in a general way that the obligations of the new pact should not be substituted for, or prejudice in any way, previous obligations contained in international instruments such as the Covenant of the League of Nations, the Locarno agreements or treaties guaranteeing neutrality whose character and scope cannot be modified thereby, then the differences of opinion which have appeared in the course of previous phases of the negotiation have to do more with words than with the reality of the problem facing the two Governments to-day.On the 27th April, 1928, the German Government informed the United States Ambassador in Berlin that " In so far as Germany is concerned the only international agreements which need be considered as liable to be affected by the provisions of the new pact are the Covenant of the League and the Locarno-Rhineland Pact; Germany had not entered into any other international engagements which could be affected by the new proposal. In the view of the German Government the observance of the obligations devolving under the Covenant of the League and the Rhineland Pact must remain immovably fixed. The German Government are, however, convinced that these obligations do not contain anything which could in any way conflict with the obligations fore-shadowed in the draft pact of the United States. On the contrary, the German Government consider that the binding obligation not to resort to war as an instrument of national policy can only tend to strengthen the basic principles of the League Covenant and the Rhineland Pact.On the 19th May, 1928, His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom informed the United States Ambassador in London that they "appreciate the scruples which have prompted the suggestions by the French Government. The exact fulfilment of treaty engagements is a matter which affects the national honour; precision as to the scope of such engagements is, therefore, ofimportance.....The preservation of peace has been the chief concern of HisMajesty's Government and the prime object of all their endeavours. It is the reason why they have given ungrudging support to the League of Nations, and why they have undertaken the burden of the guarantee embodied in the Locarno Treaty. The sole object of all these engagements is the elimination of war as an instrument of national policy, just as it is the purpose of the peace pact now proposed. It is because the object of both is the same that there is no real antagonism between the treaty engagements which His Majesty's Government have already accepted and the pact which is now proposed. The machinery of the Covenant and of the Treaty of Locarno, however, go somewhat further than a renunciation of war as a policy, in that they provide certain sanctions for a breach of their obligations. A clash might thus conceivably arise between the existing treaties and the proposed pact, unless it is understood that the obligations of the new engagement will cease to operate in respect of a party which breaks its pledges and adopts hostile measures against one of its co-contractants. For the Government of this country respect for the obligations arising out of the Covenant of the League of Nations and out of the Locarno treaties is fundamental. Our position in this regard is identical with that of the German Government as indicated in their note of the 27th April. His Majesty's Government could not agree to any new treaty which would weaken or undermine these engagements on which the peace of Europe rests. . . . Mr. Kellogg has made it clear in the speech to which I have drawn attention that he had no intention by the terms of the new treaty of preventing the parties to the Covenant of the League or to the Locarno Treaty from fulfilling their obligations." His Majesty's Government in Great Britain do not consider, after mature reflection, that the fulfilment of the obligations which they have undertaken in the Covenant of the League of Nations and in the Treaty of Locarno, is precluded by their acceptance of the proposed treaty. They concur in the view enunciated by the German Government in their note of the 27th April, that those obligations do not contain anything which could conflict with the treaty proposed by the United States Government."On the .23rd June, 1928, the United States Charge dAffaires in London informed His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom that " The Covenant imposes no affirmative primary obligation to go to war. The obligation, if any, is secondary, and attaches only when deliberately accepted by a State. Article 10 of the Covenant has, for example, been interpreted by a resolution submitted to the Fourth Assembly, but not formally adopted owing to one adverse vote, to mean that : ' It is for the constitutional authorities of each member to decide, in reference to the obligation of preserving the independence and the integrity of the territory of the members, in what degree the member is bound to assure the execution of this obligation by employment of its military forces.'
